docs.lead_paragraph: All dates are subject to change. September DANCENOW/NYC FESTIVAL -- Could the new season begin without this grass-roots event? The festival, which runs through Saturday and features more than 160 downtown and fringe artists and companies, has expanded steadily through its 10 years, sprawling out to Joe's Pub at the Public Theater, Marcus Garvey Park in Harlem, the Joyce SoHo and the drained Highbridge Park Pool in Washington Heights. (718) 850-2488. www.dancenownyc.org
docs.abstract: Roundup of fall dance offerings; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: I went to Cornwall to see the lighthouse -- Virginia Woolf's, that is, the one that stands tantalizingly out of reach until the very end of what is arguably her best novel, ''To the Lighthouse.'' The novel is Woolf's most autobiographical. (Transfixed by the portrait of their mother, her sister Vanessa wrote, ''It is almost painful to have her so raised from the dead.'') Set in the Hebrides, it is based on Woolf's recollections of idyllic childhood summers spent at St. Ives on the Cornish coast. Unlike the green light that winks at the end of the dock in F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Great Gatsby,'' the lighthouse that lends itself to the title of Woolf's novel is not merely a writerly conceit. It actually exists in the form of the Godrevy lighthouse, which you can see off in the distance from the end of the quay that runs along the pier at St. Ives. It was in search of a glimpse of this literary landmark that my 14-year-old daughter, Zoe, and I traveled early in July to the southwestern tip of England, where the country narrows down into a shape approximating a human foot.
docs.abstract: Daphne Merkin article on visit to Godrevy lighthouse, St Ives and St Mawes in Cornwall, Eng; lighthouse is one featured in Virginia Woolf's novel To the Lighthouse; photos; map (The Sophisticated Traveler, part 2 of 2-part section) (L)
docs.snippet: A summer visit to Cornwall, with its picturesque fishing villages and cozy pubs, is inspired by Virginia Woolf's lyrical novel.

docs.lead_paragraph: A spinoff, a sequel and a knockoff. Tonight NBC's first post-''Friends'' lineup looks familiar: first, ''Joey,'' about the last Friend standing, then a second round of Donald Trump in ''The Apprentice,'' followed by ''Medical Investigation,'' a ''CSI''-ish drama about epidemiologists.

headline.main: NBC Stakes Its Future On Success Of the Past

docs.abstract: Alessandra Stanley reviews Joey starring Matt LeBlanc and Drea de Matteo, The Apprentice and Medical Investigation starring Neal McDonough, all part of NBC's new television season lineup; photos (M)
docs.snippet: NBC presents a familiar lineup for its first post-"Friends" Thursday: a spinoff, a sequel and a knockoff.
